{"step_by_step_thinking": "Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is a condition characterized by damage to the white matter of the brain, specifically the periventricular region. PVL is commonly seen in premature infants and is often associated with hypoxic-ischemic injury. The most common sequelae or long-term effects of PVL include motor impairments and cognitive deficits. Spastic diplegia and spastic quadriplegia are types of motor impairments characterized by muscle stiffness and weakness. Mental retardation refers to significant cognitive deficits. Seizures can also occur as a result of brain injury. Considering the options provided, the most common sequelae due to periventricular leukomalacia are likely to be A. Spastic diplegia and B. Spastic quadriplegia.", "answer_choice": "A"}
